Title: Ni-Co-N doped honeycomb carbon nano-composites as cathodic catalysts of membrane-less direct alcohol fuel cell
Author: Li, Guang (1); Yi, Qingfeng (1, 2); Yang, Xiaokun (1); Chen, Yao (1); Zhou, Xiulin (1); Xie, Gang (2)
Author affiliation: (1) School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Hunan University of Science and Technology, Xiangtan; Hunan; 411201, China (2) The State Key Laboratory of Pressure Hydrometallurgical Technology of Associated Nonferrous Metal Resources, Kunming; Yunnan; 650503, China
Abstract: Ni-Co-N doped honeycomb carbon (HC) nano-composites Ni3Co1-N/HC (Ni3Co1-N/HC-20, Ni3Co1-N/HC-30 and Ni3Co1-N/HC-40 with respective metal mass percentage of 20%, 30% and 40%) with a regular hexagonal structure have been fabricated by using the simple polymethylmethacrylate (PMMA) emulsion template method. The side length of the carbon hexagon is ca. 100 nm for the honeycomb carbon (HC). For the Ni3Co1-N/HC catalysts, the NiCo nanoparticles and the nanocarbon tubes derived from dicyandiamide are uniformly dispersed on HCs. The as-synthesized Ni3Co1-N/HC catalysts exhibit efficient electroactivity for oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) in alkaline medium and possess excellent tolerance to the alcohols (ethanol, n-propanol and iso-propanol). Based on these results, a membrane-less direct alcohol fuel cell has been assembled with the Ni3Co1-N/HC as the cathodic catalyst, the ternary Pd7Ag2Sn2/CNT as the anodic catalyst and alcohol (ethanol, n-propanol or iso-propanol) as the fuel. The fuel cell with the Ni3Co1-N/HC-40 as the cathodic catalyst displays the open circuit voltage of 0.79 V and maximum power density of 42.2 mW cm−2 for the ethanol fuel, 0.60 V and 33.3 mW cm−2 for the n-propanol fuel, and 0.43 V and 14.4 mW cm−2 for the iso-propanol fuel. The membrane-less fuel cell also presents stable discharge performance at different discharging current densities. © 2018 Elsevier Ltd

Title: Recovery of Collided RFID Tags with Frequency Drift on Physical Layer
Author: Li, Jun-Zhi (1); Wu, Hai-Feng (1); Zeng, Yu (1); Yuan, Dong-Zhu (1)
Author affiliation: (1) School of Electrical and Information Technology, Yunnan Minzu University, Kunming; Yunnan; 650500, China
Source: Tien Tzu Hsueh Pao/Acta Electronica Sinica
Abstract: In RFID systems, the recovery of collision tag signals on a physical layer could enhance identification efficiency. However, frequency drift is very common for ultra-high frequency (UHF) RFID systems and will have an influence on the recovery on the physical layer. For the problem of the recovery with the frequency drift, this paper adopts a Radius Basis Function (RBF) network to separate the collision signals, and decode the signals based on FM0 code to recovery the collided RFID tags. The numerical results show that, the method in this paper has better performance on bit error rate (BER) and separation efficiency than conventional methods when the frequency drift occurs. © 2018, Chinese Institute of Electronics. Title: Exploring the binding pattern between pepsin and deferasirox using detailed experimental and computer simulation methods
Author: Yang, Ji (1, 2); Du, Qiaohong (1); Gan, Na (1); Chen, Yongkuan (2); Yang, Liu (2); Liu, Zhihua (2); Zhao, Hui (2); Sun, Qiaomei (1); Li, Hui (1)
Author affiliation: (1) School of Chemical Engineering, Sichuan University, Chengdu; Sichuan; 610065, China (2) RandD Center of China Tobacco Yunnan Industrial Co., Ltd., Kunming; 650231, China
Abstract: Steady-state fluorescence spectroscopy indicated that a ground state complex was formed between deferasirox (DFX) and pepsin. The binding parameters and thermodynamic parameters of pepsin-DFX complex formation suggested the presence of only one high affinity binding site in the binding process of DFX and pepsin and that the binding process was hydrogen bond dominated. According to the MD simulation optimal pepsin-DFX binding model analysis, the binding force between DFX and pepsin was mainly hydrogen bonding, and the hydrophobic interaction was supplemented. Synchronous fluorescence spectroscopy and 3D fluorescence spectroscopy indicated that the binding of DFX to pepsin had minor effect on the protein structure and function. Circular dichroism spectra showed that DFX had no significant effect on the main secondary structure of pepsin. MD analysis also showed that DFX did not affect the looseness of pepsin and the overall secondary structure, but it affected the amino acid residue sequence Leu48-Ala49-Cys50-Ser51-Asp52. Pepsin enzyme activity test showed that the addition of DFX had a slight enhancement effect on the activity of pepsin. Combined with the MD results, DFX bound to pepsin and was closer to the pepsin active site Asp-215, which may affect the electrical environment of Asp-215 residues and enhance the activity of pepsin. © The Royal Society of Chemistry.
